question: What can you conclude about Aladdin's character based on how he handles the crisis after his palace disappears?
option_1: He gives up easily when problems seem too difficult to solve and needs others to help him.
option_2: He stays calm and works with his wife to create a clever plan that solves their problem.
option_3: He becomes angry and violent, choosing to fight the magician with his own hands and weapons.
option_4: He runs away from the Sultan and hides in another country to avoid punishment forever.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Aladdin doesn't give up when things get hard. He keeps trying to solve the problem and works with his wife to make a plan.

option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Aladdin doesn't run away from the Sultan. He goes to Africa to find his wife and bring back the palace.

question: Why was it a mistake for the princess to trade the old lamp for a new one?
option_1: Because the old lamp was magic, and the magician used it to take their palace away.
option_2: Because the new lamp was shiny but did not help their family and caused trouble in the house.
option_3: Because Aladdin wanted to keep every old thing in the palace and told her never to trade anything.
option_4: Because the Sultan had a rule against trading with strangers in the street, and she broke that rule.
option_1_explanation: Exactly! You found the cause and effect. The story says the magician "rubbed the lamp" and commanded the genie to move the palace away.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The new lamp didn't cause trouble - it did nothing. The magician used the old magic lamp to steal their palace.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story never says Aladdin told her not to trade. The problem was the old lamp was magic and the magician used it.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't mention any Sultan's rule. The magician used the magic lamp to make the genie move their palace away.

article_title: Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III
passage_text:
Aladdin and the Wonderful Lamp, Part III
    
    
        Aladdin was very happy with his new life. He thought everything was perfect. But danger was coming. The evil magician heard about Aladdin's good luck."That lazy boy?" the magician said. "He married the Sultan's daughter? This must be magic from the lamp!"The magician traveled back to Persia quickly. He dressed like a poor man who sells things. He carried shiny new lamps in a basket. He walked by Aladdin's palace and shouted, "New lamps for old lamps!"Aladdin was out hunting animals. His wife, the princess, heard the voice from the street. She thought about the old, ugly lamp they had at home."I would like to trade that old lamp for a shiny new one," she thought.

---

The princess gave Aladdin's magic lamp to the magician. He gave her a new lamp that was not magic. The magician hurried away with the real lamp. Later that day, he rubbed the lamp. The powerful genie appeared in front of him."Take Aladdin's palace and everything inside it," the magician commanded. "Move it to my home in North Africa.""I hear and I obey," said the genie of the lamp.The next morning, the Sultan looked out his window. His daughter's palace was completely gone! So was the princess. He was very angry and scared. He sent his soldiers to find Aladdin. They brought Aladdin to the Sultan."Find my daughter right now!" the Sultan shouted. "If you cannot bring her back, you will die!"

---

Poor Aladdin walked far from the city. He felt very sad and worried. He walked beside a river and rubbed his hands together. He did not know what to do. Then he remembered his magic ring! He rubbed it, and the genie of the ring appeared."What do you wish?" asked the genie of the ring."Please bring my palace and my wife home to me," Aladdin begged."I am sorry," said the genie. "I cannot do that. Only the genie of the lamp can move the palace.""Then please take me to be with my wife," Aladdin said.Poof! Suddenly Aladdin was in Africa. His wife was so happy to see him! She told him about the man who traded lamps. When Aladdin heard this story, he knew the evil magician had tricked them. He knew the magician used the lamp to steal their palace. Aladdin and his wife made a plan to get the lamp back.

---

The next day, the princess cooked a wonderful dinner for the magician. Aladdin hid so the magician could not see him. The princess put poison in the magician's cup. When the magician drank from the cup, he fell down and died.Aladdin ran into the room and looked for the lamp. He found it hidden in the magician's sleeve. Aladdin rubbed the lamp, and the huge genie appeared."What do you wish?" the genie of the lamp asked in a loud voice."Take this palace with everything inside it," Aladdin commanded. "Carry it back to Persia and put it next to the Sultan's home.""I hear and I obey," the genie replied. The palace lifted up into the air and flew away.The next morning, the Sultan woke up and looked out his window. He was so happy to see his daughter and her palace again! He ordered celebrations for a whole month. From that day on, Aladdin lived peacefully and safely with the princess. When the old Sultan died, Aladdin became the new ruler. He was fair and kind to all people, both rich and poor.
question: Why is it significant that Aladdin remembers his magic ring after feeling helpless by the river?
option_1: It shows that even when things seem impossible, remembering your resources can help you find solutions.
option_2: It proves that rings are more powerful and useful than lamps in solving magical problems.
option_3: It demonstrates that walking by rivers helps people think more clearly about their difficulties.
option_4: It explains why Aladdin should have used the ring instead of the lamp from the beginning of the story.
option_1_explanation: Exactly! When Aladdin felt lost and "did not know what to do," he remembered the ring. This shows that remembering what you have can help solve problems.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the ring isn't stronger than the lamp. The ring genie can't even move the palace back like the lamp genie could.
option_3_explanation: Good try, but the river isn't the important part here. Aladdin could have remembered his ring anywhere when he felt hopeless.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say Aladdin should have picked the ring first. It shows how remembering forgotten things can help in hard times.
differentiation_notes: Targets thematic significance of the ring memory moment in paragraph 3, requiring deep inference about story meaning beyond plot - differs from reference about surface-level mistake consequences
homogeneity_check: all choices are interpretations of the significance or meaning of the ring memory moment
specificity_check: all at thematic interpretation level explaining deeper meaning
length_check: A:17 words, B:15 words, C:13 words, D:16 words - within 24% range, acceptable
semantic_distance_check: finding solutions, comparing power, river thinking, past choices are clearly distinct interpretations
single_correct_check: only A is defensible as the thematic significance supported by text
diversity_check: targets thematic meaning of specific moment in paragraph 3 - completely different from all previous variants focusing on plot, character, or actions

question: What does the ending of the story suggest about what makes a good ruler?
option_1: A good ruler must be born into a royal family and have expensive things like palaces.
option_2: A good ruler should use magic to solve all problems and make everyone wealthy and happy.
option_3: A good ruler must be fair and kind to all people, whether they are rich or poor.
option_4: A good ruler needs to be the strongest fighter who can defeat any enemy in battle.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Aladdin wasn't born rich or royal - he started as a poor boy. The story shows his good heart made him a great ruler, not fancy things.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say magic makes good rulers. It says Aladdin was "fair and kind to all people" - that's what mattered most.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story ends by saying Aladdin was "fair and kind to all people." Those good qualities made him a wonderful ruler.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Aladdin didn't win by being the strongest fighter. The story says he was "fair and kind" to everyone - that's what made him great.
differentiation_notes: Targets the final paragraph's lesson about leadership qualities, requiring interpretation of the author's choice to end with fairness and kindness - differs from reference which asks about the lamp trade mistake
homogeneity_check: all choices are qualities or requirements for being a good ruler
specificity_check: all at leadership quality description level
length_check: A:15 words, B:15 words, C:15 words, D:14 words - within 7% range, excellent balance
semantic_distance_check: royal birth, magic use, fairness/kindness, fighting strength are clearly distinct leadership qualities
single_correct_check: only C is defensible based on the story's explicit ending statement
diversity_check: targets ending paragraph's thematic message about leadership - completely different from all previous variants

question: According to the text, what is the main reason Aladdin's life changes from peaceful to dangerous?
option_1: The Sultan becomes jealous of Aladdin's wealth and happiness and wants to punish him for being successful.
option_2: The evil magician learns about Aladdin's success and comes back to steal the magic lamp through trickery.
option_3: Aladdin forgets to be careful with the lamp and accidentally loses it while out hunting in the forest.
option_4: The princess tells too many people about the magic lamp and word spreads to dangerous criminals.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The Sultan isn't jealous of Aladdin - he loves his daughter and accepted Aladdin. The evil magician is the one who causes all the trouble.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! The story says "The evil magician heard about Aladdin's good luck" and figured out the lamp was magic. He came back and tricked the princess into giving it to him.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Aladdin didn't lose the lamp while hunting - he left it safely at home. The magician tricked the princess into trading it while Aladdin was away.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the princess didn't tell anyone about the lamp. The magician already knew about it from before and heard about Aladdin's good luck.

question: How does the author show that the mistake with the lamp had serious consequences for multiple people?
option_1: The author describes how only Aladdin feels sad and worried about losing his magical powers forever.
option_2: The author shows the Sultan threatening Aladdin's life and the princess being taken far from her home.
option_3: The author explains that the magician becomes rich and powerful but treats everyone kindly with his new lamp.
option_4: The author tells how Aladdin must work hard at a regular job because he no longer has any magic to help him.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story shows that many people got hurt, not just Aladdin. The Sultan was scared and angry, and the princess was taken away too.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The text shows the Sultan was very upset and told Aladdin "you will die!" The princess was also taken far away from home.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The magician isn't kind at all - he's mean and takes the princess away. The story shows bad things happen when he gets the lamp.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Aladdin doesn't get a job in this part. The story focuses on the missing palace and the Sultan's angry threat instead.

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Alice and the White Rabbit both react in the same way when they have problems. How do they react?
option_1: worriedly
option_2: angrily
option_3: silently
option_4: bravely
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that both Alice and the Rabbit worry when they have problems. Alice "sat down and started to cry" when she couldn't reach the key.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says "The Duchess will be so angry" but that's about someone else being angry. The Rabbit is actually worried about being late.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the Rabbit isn't quiet at all! He talks to himself and says "Oh no!" when he's worried about his problem.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Running fast doesn't mean being brave here. The Rabbit runs because he's worried and scared about being late.

option_1: She gives up and stops trying.
option_2: She asks someone else for help.
option_3: She cries about her situation.
option_4: She makes a careful plan.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice doesn't give up though. She keeps trying new things like eating the cake to solve her problems.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice doesn't ask for help. She tries to fix her size problems all by herself.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says Alice "sat down and started to cry" twice when she can't solve her problems right away.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Alice doesn't make careful plans. She acts fast and gets upset when things don't work out.

She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Based on the Caterpillar's reaction to Alice, what can readers tell about his personality?
option_1: He is patient and understanding.
option_2: He is confused and curious.
option_3: He is unhelpful and uninterested.
option_4: He is friendly and talkative.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The Caterpillar doesn't show patience in this story. He stares at Alice without helping her with her size problem.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the Caterpillar doesn't really care about Alice's troubles. He asks who she is but doesn't try to understand her problem.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The Caterpillar "did not seem to understand Alice's problem" and crawls away without really helping her.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The Caterpillar isn't friendly at all. He "stared at each other for a long time without saying anything" and leaves quickly.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the Caterpillar's character traits from paragraph 4, requiring inference from his minimal dialogue and actions, different from reference which examines shared reactions between Alice and White Rabbit.
homogeneity_check: All choices are personality trait pairs
specificity_check: All use two adjectives describing character
length_check: A:5 words, B:4 words, C:4 words, D:4 words - balanced within 20%
semantic_distance_check: Each pair represents distinct personality types with clear differences
single_correct_check: Only C matches the Caterpillar's actual behavior described in text
diversity_check: Targets Caterpillar's traits in final section vs. reference examining Alice and Rabbit's shared emotional responses

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Which character trait does Alice show when she decides to explore Wonderland after getting out of the pool?
option_1: laziness
option_2: determination
option_3: confusion
option_4: fear
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice isn't lazy at all. She keeps trying new things and wants to explore, not sit around doing nothing.
option_2_explanation: You got it! Alice decides to explore even after all her troubles. She doesn't give up and keeps going on her adventure.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but confusion isn't the right trait here. Alice chooses to explore, which shows she's ready to keep trying.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Alice isn't scared when she decides to explore. If she was afraid, she would try to hide or run away.
differentiation_notes: Focuses on Alice's proactive decision-making in paragraph 3 after the pool incident, examining her motivational traits rather than emotional reactions like the reference question.
homogeneity_check: All choices are single-word character traits
specificity_check: All are abstract personality characteristics
length_check: A:1 word, B:1 word, C:1 word, D:1 word - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: Each trait is semantically distinct with no overlapping meanings
single_correct_check: Only B is supported by the text's description of Alice's active choice
diversity_check: Examines Alice's motivational trait in paragraph 3 vs. reference comparing emotional reactions of two characters

question: How does Alice's reaction to her size problems change from the beginning to the end of the passage?
option_1: She starts by crying and ends by taking action to solve her problems.
option_2: She starts by being excited and ends by feeling confused about her identity.

option_1_explanation: Great job! Alice starts by crying when she can't reach the key, but by the end she "quickly grabbed the golden key" and tries to solve her problems.

option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the order is backwards! Alice starts by trying to get the key and eating cake, then explores later in the story.
differentiation_notes: Compares White Rabbit's behavior across two story sections (his fancy return vs. his frightened reaction), analyzing character change rather than shared traits between characters.
homogeneity_check: All choices compare contrasting behavioral states
specificity_check: All use 'instead of' structure showing behavioral shifts
length_check: A:6 words, B:6 words, C:6 words, D:6 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: Each presents a different behavioral contrast with no overlaps
single_correct_check: Only B accurately describes the shift from fancy appearance to scared reaction
diversity_check: Traces one character's behavioral change across sections vs. reference examining shared reactions between two characters

The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: What key detail in the last paragraph shows that Alice finally has control over her size?
option_1: She breaks off pieces from both sides of the mushroom.
option_2: She eats tiny bites until reaching her normal size.
option_3: She stands on her toes to look at the Caterpillar.
option_4: The Caterpillar tells her which sides to use.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Breaking off pieces means she has the mushroom, but it doesn't show she can use it well. The story asks about actually controlling her size.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The words "ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size" show Alice being careful and taking control. She learned to go slow instead of eating big bites!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Standing on her toes happens before she gets help from the Caterpillar. At that part, Alice is still too small and having trouble.
option_4_explanation: Close! The Caterpillar gives Alice good advice, but that's just learning information. The question asks what shows she actually took control of her size.
differentiation_notes: Identifies the specific detail in paragraph 4 that demonstrates Alice's gained mastery, focusing on textual evidence of control rather than the method itself.
homogeneity_check: All choices are actions or events from the final paragraph
specificity_check: All describe specific textual details from the Caterpillar scene
length_check: A:10 words, B:9 words, C:9 words, D:8 words - within 20% range
semantic_distance_check: Each detail represents a different moment in the sequence
single_correct_check: Only B explicitly demonstrates Alice's careful control through action
diversity_check: Asks which detail shows control/mastery vs. reference asking what method Alice used

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: This story was most likely written to
option_1: entertain readers with a magical adventure.
option_2: help readers learn about animals.
option_3: teach readers about different types of food.
option_4: show readers how to solve problems.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You saw that this story has magic like Alice "getting smaller and smaller" to entertain us. Stories with magic adventures are written to be fun!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story has animals, but they're magical talking animals, not real facts about animals. This story is meant to entertain with magic adventures.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the cake isn't teaching us about food - it's magic that makes Alice grow! This story is written to entertain us with magical adventures.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Alice does have problems, but the story shows magical things happening, not real ways to solve problems. It's written to entertain with fun adventures.

option_1: Alice thinks changing sizes is confusing, but the Caterpillar thinks it is normal.

option_3: stay exactly the same throughout her adventure.
option_4: disappear completely after meeting each character.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice's problems don't get easier though. First she's too small, then too big, then stuck in tears - each problem gets harder!
option_2_explanation: You got it! Alice's problems pile up: "too short to reach" then "much too big to fit" then crying in a pool. They get worse before getting better!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Alice faces different problems each time. First she can't reach the key, then she's too big for the door, then she's stuck in tears.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but her problems don't go away when she meets someone. She still has size troubles even after seeing the White Rabbit again!
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the overall structural pattern across all four paragraphs, examining how the author sequences escalating problems before resolution.

specificity_check: All propose trajectories for how problems develop

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: Based on how the author organizes paragraphs 1-3, what pattern is repeated?
option_1: Alice meets someone new, then her size changes.
option_2: Alice's size changes, then she faces a new challenge.
option_3: Alice finds food, then she feels happy.
option_4: Alice solves a problem, then she finds the key.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice's size changes first, then she meets people later. The story shows her shrinking or growing before she sees anyone new.
option_2_explanation: You got it! Alice changes size, then gets stuck with a new problem. First she "was getting smaller" but couldn't reach the key!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Alice feels sad after eating, not happy. When she eats the cake, she grows too big and cries again.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice doesn't really solve her problems in these parts. She tries things that make new problems instead of fixing them.
differentiation_notes: Identifies the cause-effect pattern structure repeated in paragraphs 1-3, requiring recognition of sequence patterns rather than analyzing cumulative building.
homogeneity_check: All choices propose repeated two-step sequence patterns
specificity_check: All describe action-consequence pairs
length_check: A:9 words, B:9 words, C:7 words, D:8 words - within 22% range
semantic_distance_check: Each proposes a different two-step pattern with clear distinctions
single_correct_check: Only B accurately identifies the repeated structure in paragraphs 1-3
diversity_check: Asks about repeated structural pattern vs. reference examining single recurring problem element

option_1: She tastes them first before eating the whole thing.
option_2: She finds them in boxes with written instructions.
option_3: They cause her body size to change each time.
option_4: They always taste sweet and make her feel better.

option_1: She grows and shrinks over and over after eating or drinking.

option_2_explanation: Great job! Alice's size changes keep making new problems - she gets "smaller and smaller" then can't reach the key, then grows too big for the door.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Alice stays in the same room the whole time. She doesn't go to new rooms - she's stuck dealing with the door and table.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice isn't trying to help the White Rabbit. She's too busy with her own problems trying to get through the door.

length_check: A:4 words, B:4 words, C:5 words, D:5 words - within 20% range

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part II
    
    
        Alice had just drunk from a strange little bottle. The liquid tasted very odd and made her feel funny."What a strange feeling!" said Alice. She was getting smaller and smaller. Soon, she was only ten inches tall. Now she was the perfect size to go through the tiny door to the beautiful garden. But when Alice got to the door, she realized something terrible. She had forgotten the little golden key on the table!Alice went back to get the key, but now she had a big problem. She was too short to reach the table! Alice sat down and started to cry. Then she noticed a small glass box under the table. Inside the box was a tiny cake with the words 'EAT ME' written on top with small pieces of fruit.

---

"I will eat this cake," Alice said with excitement. As soon as she took a bite, something amazing happened."How strange!" cried Alice. "Now I am growing bigger and bigger! I can barely see my feet!" Alice grew so tall that her head hit the ceiling of the hall. She was now nine feet tall! She quickly grabbed the golden key and ran to the garden door. But now she had the opposite problem. She was much too big to fit through the doorway. All she could do was look into the garden with one eye.Alice felt so sad that she sat down and cried again. She cried so many tears that they made a big pool of water around her. While she was crying, Alice heard footsteps. It was the White Rabbit coming back! He looked very fancy with white gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other hand.

---

The White Rabbit was talking to himself. "Oh no! The Duchess will be so angry if I am late!" When Alice tried to talk to him, the Rabbit got scared. He dropped his gloves and fan and ran away quickly into the dark."Everything is so weird today!" said Alice. As she spoke, Alice noticed she was getting smaller again. Suddenly, splash! She fell into the pool of water she had made with her own tears. Poor Alice had to swim around in her own tear pool!"I wish I had not cried so much!" Alice said as she swam around looking for a way out. Alice was not the type of person to sit still and do nothing. After she got out of the pool, she decided to explore more of Wonderland.

---

Soon Alice found a large blue Caterpillar sitting on top of a mushroom. The Caterpillar was smoking a long pipe. Alice stood on her toes and looked over the edge of the mushroom. The Caterpillar and Alice stared at each other for a long time without saying anything.Finally, the Caterpillar took the pipe out of his mouth and asked, "Who are you?" Alice felt confused. "I do not really know, sir. I knew who I was this morning, but I have changed so many times today." The Caterpillar did not seem to understand Alice's problem with changing sizes.Before the Caterpillar crawled away, he told Alice something important. "One side of the mushroom will make you grow taller. The other side will make you grow shorter." Alice broke off a piece from each side of the mushroom. She ate tiny bites until she was back to her normal size.
question: How does the author structure the story to show that Alice's size problems get more complicated over time?
option_1: Each paragraph shows Alice finding a solution that creates a bigger problem than before.
option_2: Each paragraph shows Alice meeting a character who helps her solve her problems.
option_3: Each paragraph shows Alice learning a lesson that makes her smarter than before.
option_4: Each paragraph shows Alice visiting a place that is more dangerous than before.
option_1_explanation: Great job! Each time Alice tries to fix her problem, she gets a bigger one instead. First she's "too short to reach the table," then she's "much too big to fit through the doorway."
option_2_explanation: Good try! But the White Rabbit doesn't actually help Alice with her size problems. He just shows up at the very end when Alice is crying.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Alice doesn't get smarter from her mistakes. She keeps making the same kinds of choices that change her size in the wrong ways.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story isn't about dangerous places. It's about Alice's size problems getting worse each time she tries to solve them.
differentiation_notes: Analyzes the author's structural purpose for including a specific detail that connects sections, examining why the author made compositional choices.
homogeneity_check: All choices explain why the author included the tear pool detail
specificity_check: All propose authorial purposes or messages
length_check: A:8 words, B:7 words, C:7 words, D:7 words - within 12% range
semantic_distance_check: Each proposes a different authorial purpose (structure, character preference, moral lesson, character development)
single_correct_check: Only A accurately identifies the structural connection purpose
diversity_check: Examines author's structural linking purpose vs. reference asking what specific event repeats
original_question: The author includes the detail about Alice swimming in her own tears to show

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
    
    
        Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. It had no talking between people either."What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice thought to herself.It was a very hot day. The heat made Alice feel sleepy. She thought about making a chain of flowers from daisies. But she would have to get up and pick the flowers. She wondered if it would be worth all that work. Just then, a White Rabbit ran right past her!

---

At first, Alice did not think this was strange. She did not even think it was weird when the Rabbit said to itself, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I will be too late!" But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket! Alice jumped up to her feet right away. She ran after the Rabbit and watched him jump down a big rabbit hole.Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole. She did not think about how she would get back out again. The rabbit hole went down very suddenly. Alice found herself falling down what looked like a very deep well.The well was very deep, or maybe she was falling very slowly. Either way, she had lots of time to look around her. She looked at the sides of the well as she fell. There were cupboards and bookshelves all along the walls.

---

"Well!" Alice thought to herself. "After falling like this, I will never be scared of falling down stairs again!"Down, down, down she fell. Would this fall ever end? "I wonder how many miles I have fallen," Alice said out loud. "I must be getting close to the center of the earth. That would be about four thousand miles down, I think. What if I fall all the way through the earth? How funny it would be to come out where people walk upside down! I will have to ask them what their country is called."Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.

---

In front of her was a long tunnel. The White Rabbit was rushing down it. Alice ran after him. She heard him say, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I am getting!" Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.
question: What causes Alice to follow the White Rabbit down the hole?
option_1: She wants to pick daisies.
option_2: She is bored sitting by the river.
option_3: The day is very hot.
option_4: The Rabbit pulls out a watch.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice thinks about picking daisies, but she doesn't get up to do it. The story says "The Rabbit pulled a watch out" - that's what makes her jump up and follow him.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice was bored earlier by the river. The story says "The Rabbit pulled a watch out" - that amazing thing is what makes her chase after him.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The hot day makes Alice sleepy, but it doesn't make her follow the rabbit. When "The Rabbit pulled a watch out," that's when Alice jumps up to chase him.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the surprising moment that makes Alice follow the rabbit. The story says "The Rabbit pulled a watch out" and then Alice jumps up right away!

option_1: She becomes more frightened than before.

option_3: She wishes she had stayed by the river.
option_4: She wants to climb back up immediately.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice actually becomes less scared, not more frightened. She thinks falling won't scare her anymore after this big fall.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! Alice says "I will never be scared of falling" after her long fall down the well. The experience made her braver about falling.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Alice doesn't say she wants to go back to the river. She's busy looking around and exploring her new adventure.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice doesn't try to climb back up. She gets up and runs after the White Rabbit to keep following him.

I will have to ask them what their country is called."Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.

---

In front of her was a long tunnel. The White Rabbit was rushing down it. Alice ran after him. She heard him say, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I am getting!" Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.
question: What is the central message of this story about Alice's adventure?
option_1: When you're bored, something interesting will eventually happen.
option_2: You should always think carefully before making decisions.
option_3: When you are bored, you should look for something exciting to do.
option_4: Being curious can lead to amazing discoveries.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice was bored at first, but she didn't just wait for something to happen. She "ran after the Rabbit" because she was curious about its watch.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Alice "did not think about how she would get back out" when she followed the rabbit. Her curiosity, not careful thinking, led to her amazing adventure.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice wasn't just looking for any excitement. She got curious when she saw the rabbit "pulled a watch out of its pocket" and followed it to discover new things.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You saw how Alice's curiosity led to discoveries. When "the Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket," Alice followed it and found amazing new places.

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
passage_text:

        Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. option_3: Following your curiosity can open up new worlds.
option_4: Hot days are the best time to have adventures.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The watch belongs to the Rabbit, not Alice. The story shows how Alice's curiosity leads her to amazing discoveries.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's just why Alice was bored at first. The real lesson is about how curiosity can lead to wonderful adventures.
option_3_explanation: Great job! Alice's curiosity about the "White Rabbit" leads her into Wonderland's amazing world. Following what interests us opens up new experiences.

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
    
    
        Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. It had no talking between people either."What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice thought to herself.It was a very hot day. The heat made Alice feel sleepy. She thought about making a chain of flowers from daisies. But she would have to get up and pick the flowers. She wondered if it would be worth all that work. Just then, a White Rabbit ran right past her!

---

At first, Alice did not think this was strange. She did not even think it was weird when the Rabbit said to itself, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I will be too late!" But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket! Alice jumped up to her feet right away. She ran after the Rabbit and watched him jump down a big rabbit hole.Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole. She did not think about how she would get back out again. The rabbit hole went down very suddenly. Alice found herself falling down what looked like a very deep well.The well was very deep, or maybe she was falling very slowly. Either way, she had lots of time to look around her. She looked at the sides of the well as she fell. There were cupboards and bookshelves all along the walls.

---

"Well!" Alice thought to herself. "After falling like this, I will never be scared of falling down stairs again!"Down, down, down she fell. Would this fall ever end? "I wonder how many miles I have fallen," Alice said out loud. "I must be getting close to the center of the earth. That would be about four thousand miles down, I think. What if I fall all the way through the earth? How funny it would be to come out where people walk upside down! I will have to ask them what their country is called."Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.

---

In front of her was a long tunnel. The White Rabbit was rushing down it. Alice ran after him. She heard him say, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I am getting!" Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.
question: Which pair of events from the story shows how one part leads directly to the next?
option_1: Alice sits by the river, then she picks daisies.
option_2: The Rabbit pulls out a watch, then Alice chases him down the hole.
option_3: Alice falls down the well, then she reads her sister's book.
option_4: Alice finds a golden key, then she sits by the river.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice thinks about picking daisies but decides it's too much work. She never actually picks them in the story.
option_2_explanation: You got it! When the Rabbit pulls out the watch, "Alice jumped up to her feet right away." One thing made the other happen!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but these events happen backwards! Alice reads her sister's book first, then falls down the well later.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Alice finds the golden key after she falls down the hole. The story doesn't happen in this order.
differentiation_notes: Targets the cause-effect relationship between specific events in paragraphs 2-3 - differs from reference which asks about outline completion. This requires identifying correct sequential connections.
homogeneity_check: all choices are two-event sequences with causal implications
specificity_check: all describe pairs of specific story events
length_check: A:10 words, B:12 words, C:11 words, D:10 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each presents different event pairs
single_correct_check: only B presents events in correct order with clear causation
diversity_check: targets specific cause-effect between watch and chase - different from reference about outline structure

question: Why did the author write this story about Alice?
option_1: to explain what a rabbit hole is like
option_2: to tell about a girl's unusual adventure
option_3: to invite readers to go on an exciting adventure
option_4: to show how to follow a white rabbit
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story isn't about explaining rabbit holes - it's about Alice's weird adventure with a talking rabbit. The story tells us about all the strange things that happen to Alice.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You saw that this story is about Alice's strange adventure with "a White Rabbit" who talks and has a watch. The author wants to tell us about all the unusual things that happen to Alice.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't talk to you or ask you to come along. It just tells us what Alice does when she follows the rabbit. The author is telling Alice's adventure story.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't teach how to follow a rabbit - it tells about Alice's weird adventure. Alice falls down a hole and finds strange things like bottles that say "DRINK ME."

It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.
question: How does the author want readers to feel about Alice's decision to drink from the bottle?
option_1: The author wants readers to think Alice is being smart and careful.
option_2: The author wants readers to see Alice as dangerously careless.
option_3: The author wants readers to admire Alice's brave curiosity.
option_4: The author wants readers to worry that Alice will get sick.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Alice does check for poison, but the story shows her being brave and curious. The author wants us to see Alice as an adventurer, not just careful.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The author doesn't make Alice seem careless or dangerous. The bottle tastes "like cherry pie, custard, pineapple" and nothing bad happens to her.
option_3_explanation: Exactly! The author makes the bottle sound magical and taste "like cherry pie, custard, pineapple." Alice's choice to drink it shows her brave curiosity.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't make us worry about Alice getting sick. The drink tastes wonderful and the author makes it seem exciting, not scary.

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part I
    
    
        Alice was getting very tired of sitting by her sister near the river. There was nothing fun to do. She looked at her sister's book once or twice. But the book had no pictures in it. It had no talking between people either."What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice thought to herself.It was a very hot day. The heat made Alice feel sleepy. She thought about making a chain of flowers from daisies. But she would have to get up and pick the flowers. She wondered if it would be worth all that work. Just then, a White Rabbit ran right past her!

---

At first, Alice did not think this was strange. She did not even think it was weird when the Rabbit said to itself, "Oh dear! Oh dear! I will be too late!" But then something amazing happened. The Rabbit pulled a watch out of its pocket! Alice jumped up to her feet right away. She ran after the Rabbit and watched him jump down a big rabbit hole.Alice followed the Rabbit down the hole. She did not think about how she would get back out again. The rabbit hole went down very suddenly. Alice found herself falling down what looked like a very deep well.The well was very deep, or maybe she was falling very slowly. Either way, she had lots of time to look around her. She looked at the sides of the well as she fell. There were cupboards and bookshelves all along the walls.

---

"Well!" Alice thought to herself. "After falling like this, I will never be scared of falling down stairs again!"Down, down, down she fell. Would this fall ever end? "I wonder how many miles I have fallen," Alice said out loud. "I must be getting close to the center of the earth. That would be about four thousand miles down, I think. What if I fall all the way through the earth? How funny it would be to come out where people walk upside down! I will have to ask them what their country is called."Alice was starting to fall asleep when suddenly, thump! She landed on a pile of sticks and dry leaves. Alice was not hurt at all. She got up and looked around.

---

In front of her was a long tunnel. The White Rabbit was rushing down it. Alice ran after him. She heard him say, "Oh my ears and whiskers, how late I am getting!" Alice thought she was catching up to the White Rabbit. But when she turned the corner, he was gone!Alice found herself in a long, low room. There were many doors, but they were all locked. She wondered how she would ever get out. Then she saw a little table with three legs. It was made of clear glass. On top was a tiny, golden key. But the key would not open any of the doors.Then Alice saw a curtain she had not seen before. Behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high. She tried the little golden key in the lock. It worked! The door led to a small tunnel. Alice looked through and saw the most beautiful garden ever. She wanted to leave the dark room and walk in the garden. But the doorway was too tiny. She could not even fit her head through it.Alice went back to the table. This time, she found a little bottle on it. "That was not there before," said Alice. The bottle had a label that said 'DRINK ME.' Alice looked to see if it said Poison anywhere. It did not, so Alice decided to taste it. It tasted like many good things mixed together. It was like cherry pie, custard, pineapple, turkey, candy, and buttered toast all at once. Alice drank it all up.
question: How does the narrator tell this story differently than Alice would tell it herself?
option_1: The narrator describes what Alice thinks and feels inside her mind.
option_2: The narrator only tells about things that really happened to Alice.
option_3: The narrator makes Alice sound more scared than she really was.
option_4: The narrator tells the story much faster than Alice experienced it.
option_1_explanation: Exactly! The narrator tells us what Alice thinks like "What good is a book without pictures or talking?" Alice wouldn't describe her own thoughts that way.
option_2_explanation: Good try! But the narrator tells about magical things like a talking rabbit with a watch. These aren't real things that happened.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice isn't very scared in the story. She follows the rabbit bravely and looks around calmly while falling.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The narrator gives lots of details about Alice's fall and thoughts. This shows the same slow pace Alice felt.
differentiation_notes: Targets contrasting perspectives between narrator and sister character - differs from reference which asks about author's purpose. This requires distinguishing between narrator's treatment and a character's likely viewpoint.
homogeneity_check: all choices contrast narrator and sister perspectives
specificity_check: all describe how two viewpoints differ
length_check: A:16 words, B:14 words, C:14 words, D:14 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: each presents different perspective contrasts
single_correct_check: only A accurately contrasts narrator's magical presentation with realistic character view
diversity_check: contrasts narrator vs character perspective - different from reference about author's purpose
original_question: How is the narrator's view of Alice's adventure different from what Alice's sister might think?

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part III
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part III
    
    
        Alice kept walking through Wonderland until she found a strange cat sitting on a tree branch. This was the Cheshire Cat, and he had a huge grin on his face. Alice was getting tired of all the odd things in Wonderland. She wanted to find her way home."Cheshire Cat," Alice said politely, "can you please tell me which way I should go from here?""That depends on where you want to go," said the Cat with his big smile."I don't really care where I go," Alice replied."Then it doesn't matter which path you take," the Cat said back to her."I just want to get somewhere," Alice added quickly."Oh, you will definitely get somewhere if you keep walking long enough," said the Cat.

---

Alice tried asking another question. "What kind of people live around here?"The Cat pointed his right paw in one direction. "Over that way lives a Mad Hatter. Over there lives a March Hare. You can visit either one if you want. But they are both completely mad.""I don't want to visit crazy people," Alice said with worry."You can't help that here," said the Cat. "Everyone in this place is mad, including me and you!"Then something very strange happened. The Cat began to disappear slowly. First his tail vanished, then his body, and finally everything was gone except his grin. The smile stayed floating in the air for a while after the rest of him had disappeared."How curious!" Alice thought to herself. "A grin without a cat! I have never seen anything like that before!"

---

Alice continued walking until she came to a house. In front of the house was a large table set up for tea time. The March Hare and the Mad Hatter were sitting at the table having tea. Between them sat a sleepy Dormouse. Even though the table was very big, all three of them were crowded together at just one corner."No room! No room!" they shouted when they saw Alice coming toward them."There is plenty of room!" Alice said angrily. She sat down in a big chair at the end of the table."Have some lemonade," the March Hare offered.Alice looked around the whole table carefully. "I don't see any lemonade anywhere," she said."There isn't any lemonade," the March Hare replied."Then it was not very nice of you to offer it to me," Alice said with anger."It was not very nice of you to sit down when nobody invited you," the March Hare shot back.

---

The Mad Hatter stared at Alice for a long time. Finally, he asked, "Why is a raven like a writing desk?""A riddle!" Alice thought excitedly. "This should be fun to solve!""I think I can figure that out," she said out loud."Do you really think you know the answer?" asked the March Hare."Yes, I do," said Alice confidently."Then you should say exactly what you mean," the March Hare continued."I do say what I mean. At least, I mean what I say. That's the same thing," Alice replied."Those are not the same thing at all!" said the Mad Hatter. "You might as well say that 'I see what I eat' means the same thing as 'I eat what I see!'"The sleepy Dormouse added, "You might as well say that 'I breathe when I sleep' is the same as 'I sleep when I breathe!'"The Mad Hatter turned back to Alice. "Have you solved the riddle yet?""No, I give up," Alice said. "What is the answer?""I have no idea," said the Mad Hatter."Neither do I," said the March Hare.Alice thought to herself, "This is the strangest tea party I have ever been to in my whole life!" She listened as the Dormouse told a very odd story about three sisters who lived at the bottom of a well made of syrup. Alice asked many questions because the story was so confusing. Finally, she got frustrated and walked away. "That really was the strangest tea party ever!" Alice concluded to herself as she left.
question: What does Alice do first when she arrives at the tea party?
option_1: She listens to the Dormouse tell a story about sisters.
option_2: She looks around the table for lemonade to drink.
option_3: She sits down in a big chair at the end of the table.
option_4: She asks the Mad Hatter to solve a riddle for her.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The Dormouse story happens later in the tea party. Alice first "sat down in a big chair" when she arrived.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but Alice looks for lemonade after she sits down. The story says she "sat down in a big chair" first.
option_3_explanation: Great job! You found exactly what Alice did first. The story says "She sat down in a big chair at the end of the table."
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The Mad Hatter asks Alice the riddle, not the other way around. Alice "sat down in a big chair" first.

She listened as the Dormouse told a very odd story about three sisters who lived at the bottom of a well made of syrup. Alice asked many questions because the story was so confusing. Finally, she got frustrated and walked away. "That really was the strangest tea party ever!" Alice concluded to herself as she left.

article_title: Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part III
passage_text:
Alices Adventures in Wonderland, Part III
    
    
        Alice kept walking through Wonderland until she found a strange cat sitting on a tree branch. This was the Cheshire Cat, and he had a huge grin on his face. Alice was getting tired of all the odd things in Wonderland. She wanted to find her way home."Cheshire Cat," Alice said politely, "can you please tell me which way I should go from here?""That depends on where you want to go," said the Cat with his big smile."I don't really care where I go," Alice replied."Then it doesn't matter which path you take," the Cat said back to her."I just want to get somewhere," Alice added quickly."Oh, you will definitely get somewhere if you keep walking long enough," said the Cat.

---

Alice tried asking another question. "What kind of people live around here?"The Cat pointed his right paw in one direction. "Over that way lives a Mad Hatter. Over there lives a March Hare. You can visit either one if you want. But they are both completely mad.""I don't want to visit crazy people," Alice said with worry."You can't help that here," said the Cat. "Everyone in this place is mad, including me and you!"Then something very strange happened. The Cat began to disappear slowly. First his tail vanished, then his body, and finally everything was gone except his grin. The smile stayed floating in the air for a while after the rest of him had disappeared."How curious!" Alice thought to herself. "A grin without a cat! I have never seen anything like that before!"

---

Alice continued walking until she came to a house. In front of the house was a large table set up for tea time. The March Hare and the Mad Hatter were sitting at the table having tea. Between them sat a sleepy Dormouse. Even though the table was very big, all three of them were crowded together at just one corner."No room! No room!" they shouted when they saw Alice coming toward them."There is plenty of room!" Alice said angrily. She sat down in a big chair at the end of the table."Have some lemonade," the March Hare offered.Alice looked around the whole table carefully. "I don't see any lemonade anywhere," she said."There isn't any lemonade," the March Hare replied."Then it was not very nice of you to offer it to me," Alice said with anger."It was not very nice of you to sit down when nobody invited you," the March Hare shot back.

---

The Mad Hatter stared at Alice for a long time. Finally, he asked, "Why is a raven like a writing desk?""A riddle!" Alice thought excitedly. "This should be fun to solve!""I think I can figure that out," she said out loud."Do you really think you know the answer?" asked the March Hare."Yes, I do," said Alice confidently."Then you should say exactly what you mean," the March Hare continued."I do say what I mean. At least, I mean what I say. That's the same thing," Alice replied."Those are not the same thing at all!" said the Mad Hatter. "You might as well say that 'I see what I eat' means the same thing as 'I eat what I see!'"The sleepy Dormouse added, "You might as well say that 'I breathe when I sleep' is the same as 'I sleep when I breathe!'"The Mad Hatter turned back to Alice. "Have you solved the riddle yet?""No, I give up," Alice said. "What is the answer?""I have no idea," said the Mad Hatter."Neither do I," said the March Hare.Alice thought to herself, "This is the strangest tea party I have ever been to in my whole life!" She listened as the Dormouse told a very odd story about three sisters who lived at the bottom of a well made of syrup. Alice asked many questions because the story was so confusing. Finally, she got frustrated and walked away. "That really was the strangest tea party ever!" Alice concluded to herself as she left.
question: What does the March Hare offer Alice, even though there isn't any?
option_1: A cup of tea
option_2: Lemonade
option_3: A plate of cookies
option_4: A big slice of cake
option_1_explanation: Good try! Tea makes sense at a tea party, but this story doesn't mention the March Hare offering tea. The story actually says he offered something else to drink.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading carefully. The story shows exactly what the March Hare offered Alice.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but cookies aren't mentioned in this part of the story. The March Hare offered Alice a drink, not food.
option_4_explanation: Close! Cake sounds like something at a tea party, but the story doesn't mention cake. The March Hare offered Alice something to drink instead.

"What is the answer?""I have no idea," said the Mad Hatter."Neither do I," said the March Hare.Alice thought to herself, "This is the strangest tea party I have ever been to in my whole life!" She listened as the Dormouse told a very odd story about three sisters who lived at the bottom of a well made of syrup. Alice asked many questions because the story was so confusing. Finally, she got frustrated and walked away. "That really was the strangest tea party ever!" Alice concluded to herself as she left.
